Award.AwardTitle: Increasing Underrepresented Minorities in STEM: The 45th Annual National Organization of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded by the Special Projects Program of the Chemistry Division of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate. The Principle Investigator is Emanuel Waddell of the University of Alabama in Huntsville. This activity supports the participation of 135 undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral students at the 45th Annual National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) conference, held Sept. 17 - 20, 2018 in Orlando, FL. Selected participants are from underrepresented minority groups in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields.

This award provides opportunities for participants to engage in four major areas of focus: 1) technical and professional development; 2) networking and mentorship opportunities with professionals working in STEM fields; 3) exposure to high-profile minority role models in STEM; and 4) academic and professional STEM career advancement opportunities. Student participants interact with peers and professionals from industry, government, and academia to develop collaborations and to explore opportunities to pursue graduate degrees in the chemistry or chemical engineering disciplines. These opportunities may not only impact these specific participating individuals, but also benefit the larger community of STEM field practitioners as these activities are useful in recruiting and retaining individuals from underrepresented talent pools. NOBCChE seeks to increase the number of minorities in the STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 45th Annual National Organization of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) Conference took place in Orlando, FL from September 17-20, 2019 at the Rosen Centre at 9840 International Drive. The conference theme was "NOBCChE on the Move". The conference had approximately 800 attendees that consisted of 135 undergraduate and graduate students supported by the National Science Foundation. These students participated in professional development sessions and presented technical posters and oral presentations that covered areas of chemistry and chemical engineering. The students represented public and private universities inclusive of historically black colleges and universities, predominantly white universities and other minority serving institutions.

 

Students attending the conference participated in four major areas: 1) STEM Professional and Technical Development; 2) STEM Executive Coaching, Mentoring and Networking Opportunities; 3) Exposure to Prestigious Minority Models in STEM and 4) Academic and Professional STEM Career Advancement Opportunities. Highlights included a session sponsored by GEM Grad Lab which encouraged students to pursue graduate degrees and provided insight into the graduate school application process and funding opportunities. A patent and intellectual property attorney organized a Patents Lifecycle Skit and Intellectual Property Panel. Students received free resume reviews, networking tips and an opportunity to practice their skills during the career fair which had 69 exhibitors. The Percy L. Julian award recipient was Dr. Bobby Wilson from Texas Southern University who discussed his chemical research career and life story. Several students received offers of internships and received interviews at the conference.

 

An evaluation of the student attendees indicated that the conference enhanced their identity as scientists and engineers. The students also experiences an increased sense of belonging to a community of chemists and chemical engineers.  The evaluation of the attendees indicate that the majority were female and attend predominantly white, research one universities. The majority of students were not first generation college students. The male students who attend the conference exhibited a greater sense of belonging than the female students. 

 

These results indicate that the NOBCChE conference provides an intellectual and emotional support system for under-represented students on predominantly white campuses. This support system is vital to increasing a students sense of belonging and long term retention in chemistry and chemical engineering.
